summary: The Foreign Adversary Risk Management Act (FARM Act) amends the Defense Production Act of 1950 to protect U.S. agriculture from foreign influence. It includes U.S. agriculture in the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) reviews, expanding scrutiny of foreign investments. The bill also classifies agricultural supply chains as critical infrastructure and critical technologies. Furthermore, it mandates reports from the Secretary of Agriculture and the Comptroller General on foreign investments in U.S. agriculture and their potential risks.
